content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said the trade deal with China will work out because of tariffs and that China will make a deal because they have to, while he believes that China are absolutely devaluing the CNY to offset tariffs. Furthermore, Trump commented that tariffs will rise if a deal with China is not made and that he thinks he will meet with Chinese President Xi at the G20 summit in Osaka but added that its fine if they don't and that the next USD 300bln of tariffs will come into effect if Chinese President Xi does not come to the G20. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

BoE's Saunders (Hawk) said the BoE will likely need to return to neutral policy stance sooner than the market expects and that the MPC doesn't necessarily need to keep rates unchanged until Brexit uncertainties are resolved. Saunders added that BoE's neutral rate is around 2% and suggested that they should not just look at Brexit uncertainty and instead should look at growth as well as assess whether or not it is above or below potential when setting interest rate. (Newswires)

UK right-wing Tory caucus held a non-binding vote to gauge support in which Boris Johnson received the most votes, while there were comments from UK Tory MP Iain Duncan Smith that he has decided to support Boris Johnson in the leadership election and backs him to deliver Brexit. (Newswires/Telegraph)

ECB's de Guindos stated that the governing council is determined to act in the case of adverse contingencies and the ECB is ready to adjust all instruments if it is appropriate. (Newswires)

US

President Trump later commented that the US has an agreement on something with Mexico that they will announce very soon and that he does not think Mexico will be denying for very long the undisclosed portion of the agreement. (Newswires/Twitter)

Mexican President Obrador said he expects the Mexican senate to approve the USMCA deal next week. In other news, Mexican Foreign Minister Ebrard answered that there is no additional agreement with the US when asked about US President Trump's announcement that Mexico will buy large numbers of agricultural goods from US farmers, while he added that there is no specific target for the reduction of migrant flows in the deal with the US. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

United Technologies (UTX) reversed pre-market gains related to the defence contractors proposed tie up with Raytheon (RTN), as news emerged that Boeing (BA) are to review the merger. Raytheon and Boeing shares moved both moved higher. Kraft Heinz (KHC) advanced after the co announced that the company's internal investigation into its procurement area and assessment of internal controls is complete, and the food maker continues to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation. Salesforce.com (CRM) shares were hit after the co. announced plans to buy Tableau Software Inc (DATA) for an enterprise value of USD 15.7bln in an all-stock deal (whose stock price skyrocketed). Financials (C, JPM, WFC, GS, BAC) benefitted from a rising yield environment. Analog Devices Inc (ADI) advanced after an analyst at Goldman Sachs gave the semiconductor company a double upgrade to buy from sell. Insys Therapeutics (INSY) lost nearly half of its market cap after the drug maker filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after the co. allegedly paid bribes to doctors who prescribed a specific opioid medication. LyondellBasell (LYB) jumped higher after saying it launched a modified Dutch Auction tender offer to purchase as much as 37M ordinary shares. The casino sector had a good day; Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) all moved higher after Deutsche Bank raised its recommendation for the Macau sector. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher after receiving an upgrade from Roth Capital. Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP) sunk on a downgrade from Credit Suisse. S&P 500 0.5% AT 2887, NASDAQ 100 1.1% AT 7502, DJIA 0.3% AT 26062.

Yields are higher across the curve, amid a more constructive risk tone after the US decided against implementing tariffs on Mexican imports. However, some attribute higher yields to positioning ahead of this week’s supply, with attention on whether foreign buyers are willing to scoop up Treasuries at the recently lower yields. Additionally, some will be mindful of the FOMC meeting next week, and for any nod to the recent dovish pricing of the FOMC rate trajectory (will the Fed shift from neutral to an easing bias?). There is also the CPI report on Wednesday, where a lower print might squash yields down towards the bottom of the recent ranges; conversely, CPI above expectations and a strong retail sales report (Friday) could provide a hurdle to the bullish thesis running in Treasuries. Monday also saw a large amount of corporate; IFR noted that high grade supply looked set to head towards USD 15bln or more on the day. At settlement, yields at the belly of the curve saw the most pronounced move, 10-year yield up just over 6bps, with the 2s/10s steepening c. 1.1bps. US T-note futures (M9) settled 14+ ticks lower at 126-14.

subject: US MARKET WRAP - 10 JUNE 2019: Trump ramps up pressure on China; Risk assets rally in afterglow of Mexico deal
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: US President Trump threatens more tariffs if no meeting with Xi at G20, US/Mexico strike a deal over weekend and tariffs averted, Treasury Sec Mnuchin says Huawei ban could be lifted in event of a deal, Sources suggest ECB may be ready for more cuts, US mulling further Iran sanctions, JOLTS consistent with labour market slowdown, Weak UK GDP, BoE’s Saunders fairly Hawkish

* COMING UP: JN Broad Money, AU Business Conditions, UK employment data, US Business Optimism, PPI final, API Weekly Inventories, NZ Electric Card Retail Sales, ECB’s Nowotny, Rehn, BoE’s Vlieghe, Tenreyro

* TRUMP INTERVIEW: In a wide-ranging live interview on CNBC, US President Trump said the trade deal with China will work out because tariffs are powerful tool. He suggested that China will make a deal because 'they will have to make a deal'. He also accused china of devaluing the yuan in order to offset the impact of tariffs. Trump warned that if a deal was not made with China, then tariffs will rise; he also said that if China President Xi did not attend the G20, tariffs would be implemented on the USD 300bln of remaining Chinese imports. Trump hinted that he was due to meet Xi at the 28-29th June G20 meeting. Elsewhere, Trump critiqued the Fed again, saying it had made a mistake by raising rates while implementing QT.

* MEXICO: US/Mexico struck a deal late Friday, averting US tariffs on Mexican goods imports. Details were thin (US President Trump has pledged to provide more colour), though watchers said the deal largely consists of actions that Mexico had already promised recently. Trump also suggested that, seemingly as part of the deal, Mexico will be raising purchases of US agricultural goods, though this was not explicit in the accord. Mexico’s Foreign Minister Ebrard later confirmed that agricultural purchases had not been part of the deal and noted that the deal also did not specify a target for the reduction of migrant flows. The deal has raised hopes that the US might take a similar approach to China negotiations, although the issues seem deeper, and more challenging to resolve, and as such, hurdles remain high.

* G20: G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Chiefs joint communique stated they pledge to use all the policies they can to protect global growth from disruptions due to trade and other tensions, while it added that risks from trade and geopolitical tensions are "intensifying". Moreover, the ministers agreed to create common rules to close loopholes used by global tech giants, including Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB), to reduce their corporate taxes, as stated in a final communique.

* CHINA: Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has suggested that US could ease sanctions on Huawei if US President Trump secured guarantees from the Chinese government. The remarks are in keeping with the position of US President Trump’s, who has previously suggested that the telecoms giant could be included as part of a trade deal with China. The Treasury Secretary also said it was no coincidence that Chinese policymakers had allowed the yuan to weaken, of late. Later in the session, the US State Department expressed its “grave concern” over Hong Kong's proposed extradition law, against which hundreds of thousands of protestors marched over the weekend.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Turkey is still pressing forward with its plans to acquire Russia’s S-400 missile defence system, in a move which will strain tensions between the White House and Ankara. Turkey said the US had not taken any steps to participate in the proposed bilateral study of the S-400. It is now becoming more likely that the US will evict Turkey from the F-35 jet training programme, as it had previously threatened. Elsewhere, UN Nuclear Watchdog Chief Amano stated that Iran's rate of production of enriched uranium is now increasing. This came shortly after comments from the Iran Foreign Ministry suggested that the EU has not taken practical measures to revive the Nuclear Deal (which despite the US’ opposition to the deal, Iran is pressing on Europe to maintain it). Later reports emerged that the US government was mulling further Iran sanctions that would focus on Iran's special trade and finance institute (which works with Europe's Instex).

* JOLTS JOB OPENINGS: April US JOLTS Job openings ticked slightly lower in April (7.449mln vs prev. 7.488mln), alongside seeing a negatively revised March figure to 7.474mln. Hires, however, jumped by 240k to a record high of 5.937mln, with the hires rate rising by 0.1ppts to 3.9%, the highest level since January. Separations also rose marginally to 5.578mln, but the rate remained unchanged. Looking at the longer-term trend these figures remain consistent with labour demand levelling off, and Wells Fargo have suggested that the slowdown noted in last week’s payrolls numbers have been offered further credence; but that the largely unchanged quits rate suggests that the labour market is not “falling off of the rails”.

* CHINA TRADE DATA:  China’s trade surplus widened, as imports fell more than forecast, but exports were slightly better than the Street had pencilled in. Exports to the US continue to decline, as do imports. The better exports data might be driven by front-loading, with Chinese exporters hoping to ship their goods before tariffs are raised on Chinese goods. Meanwhile, Chinese FX reserves rose to USD 3.101trln in April, a nine-month high. China CPI data due tomorrow and activity data at the end of the week are the next data points to watch.

* BREXIT: Former UK foreign secretary Boris Johnson, the leading candidate to become Conservative Party leader, on the weekend threatened to withhold the GBP 39bln Brexit ‘divorce bill’ if no EU deal can be reached, also warning that there was a very small possibility that no deal can be found. Johnson also vowed to tear-up former UK PM May’s deal and re-open negotiations with the EU, contrary to the assertions from EU policymakers that this was not possible (currently, EU policymakers seem to be taking a wait-and-see approach as to how the leadership race turns out). Johnson also said he’d cut income tax for top earners, raising the top-rate 40% threshold to £80k were he elected. Meanwhile, UK GDP in April was weaker than anticipated, reflecting the front-loading stockpiling seen in Q1, and the data augurs poorly for the Q2 GDP print. Elsewhere, the EU is to warn businesses not to expect any help regarding a no-deal Brexit and urges them to prepare for the UK to crash out of the EU on October 31st. Finally, the conservative leadership election officially started on Monday. For a full-timetable of the election process, click here.

* ECB: The ECB is open to cutting the rates again if growth weakens in the rest of the year as a strong euro is hurting the bloc, according to two sources cited by Reuters. The report was followed by supported comments from the ECB’s Visco at the weekend G20 meeting. ECB President candidate Weidmann, however, said that there’s less scope for policy to react to the current slowdown in the euro area economy, and that policymakers should not delay normalisation.

* BOE: BOE’s Haldane (hawk) wrote an op-ed stating that the central bank should consider higher rates to “nip any inflationary risks in the bud,” citing risks from to real pay. BOE’s Saunders (also typically hawkish) said that the BoE will likely need to return to neutral policy stance sooner than the market expects, which he said was around 2%, although tightening is likely to be limited and gradual. He said the MPC doesn't necessarily need to keep rates unchanged until Brexit uncertainties are resolved, and said that in the event of a no deal Brexit, rates could move in either direction. Saunders noted that when setting interest rates, the BoE should not just look at Brexit uncertainty but should look at growth and assess whether or not it is above or below potential. When asked about the recent GDP data, Saunders responded that the Bank has repeatedly said data is likely to be volatile (suggesting that the Bank will not place too much importance on one data point) whilst also stating that bankers had expected Q2 weakness as a result of the unwinding of Q1 stockpiling.

* THIS WEEK’S TREASURY SUPPLY: The US will auction USD 78bln in 3-year (USD 38bln, Tue), 10-year (USD 24bln, Weds), 30-year (USD 16bln, Thu). With USD 24bln maturing at the mid-month settlement, the supply will raise a net USD 54bln of new cash. TD Securities points out that the Fed’s portfolio run-off has slowed to USD 15bln in Treasuries, versus USD 30bln previous, however, with no SOMA maturities in the mid-month, the Fed is set to conduct its add-ons later in the month.

* 3-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Recent auctions have been mixed, with some desks suggesting that lower rates are a factor. With that said, recent speculation that the Fed could fire some “insurance” rate cuts might be supportive. Recent averages suggest we could see a tail at the 3-year auction of 0.3bps, with 61% buy-side takedown (16% to directs, and 45% to indirects).

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 14+ TICKS LOWER AT 126-14: Yields are higher across the curve, amid a more constructive risk tone after the US decided against implementing tariffs on Mexican imports. However, some attribute higher yields to positioning ahead of this week’s supply, with attention on whether foreign buyers are willing to scoop up Treasuries at the recently lower yields. Additionally, some will be mindful of the FOMC meeting next week, and for any nod to the recent dovish pricing of the FOMC rate trajectory (will the Fed shift from neutral to an easing bias?). There is also the CPI report on Wednesday, where a lower print might squash yields down towards the bottom of the recent ranges; conversely, CPI above expectations and a strong retail sales report (Friday) could provide a hurdle to the bullish thesis running in Treasuries. Monday also saw a large amount of corporate; IFR noted that high grade supply looked set to head towards USD 15bln or more on the day. At settlement, yields at the belly of the curve saw the most pronounced move, 10-year yield up just over 6bps, with the 2s/10s steepening c. 1.1bps.

* WTI (N9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.73 LOWER AT USD 53.26/BBL; BRENT (Q9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 1.00 LOWER AT USD 62.29/BBL: Energy markets drifted lower throughout the US session, failing to hold onto overnight gains. Prices initially got off on the front foot following US President Trump’s decision to not implement tariffs on Mexico. Russian officials said on Monday that they see extended downside for prices if supply cuts aren’t extended (citing USD 40/bbl and USD 30/bbl) and want a balanced oil market, essentially indicating to domestic producers to buckle up as they move towards falling in line with the rest of OPEC+.

* S&P 500 0.5% AT 2887, DOW JONES 1.1% AT 7502, NASDAQ-100 0.3% AT 26062; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 1.1%, Consumer Staples 0%, Energy 0.3%, Financials 0.9%, Health Care 0.3%, Industrials 0.1%, Information Technology 1%, Materials 0.1%, Telecommunication Services -0.2%, Utilities -0.6%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: United Technologies (UTX) reversed pre-market gains related to the defence contractors proposed tie up with Raytheon (RTN), as news emerged that Boeing (BA) are to review the merger. Raytheon and Boeing shares moved both moved higher. Kraft Heinz (KHC) advanced after the co announced that the company's internal investigation into its procurement area and assessment of internal controls is complete, and the food maker continues to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation. Salesforce.com (CRM) shares were hit after the co. announced plans to buy Tableau Software Inc (DATA) for an enterprise value of USD 15.7bln in an all-stock deal (whose stock price skyrocketed). Financials (C, JPM, WFC, GS, BAC) benefitted from a rising yield environment. Analog Devices Inc (ADI) advanced after an analyst at Goldman Sachs gave the semiconductor company a double upgrade to buy from sell. Insys Therapeutics (INSY) lost nearly half of its market cap after the drug maker filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after the co. allegedly paid bribes to doctors who prescribed a specific opioid medication. LyondellBasell (LYB) jumped higher after saying it launched a modified Dutch Auction tender offer to purchase as much as 37M ordinary shares. The casino sector had a good day; Wynn Resorts (WYNN), MGM Resorts (MGM) and Las Vegas Sands (LVS) all moved higher after Deutsche Bank raised its recommendation for the Macau sector. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher after receiving an upgrade from Roth Capital. Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP) sunk on a downgrade from Credit Suisse.

* FX WRAP: USD has been clawing back losses incurred after Friday’s weak jobs report, albeit largely due to weakness in other FX majors. Looking ahead, dollar traders await this week’s CPI and Retail Sales data releases, which will be considered at next week’s FOMC meeting. MXN rebounded sharply the US and Mexico agreed upon a deal that averts tariffs on the US’ imports of Mexican goods, USDMXN pressing back toward 19. CNY gapped lower over the weekend, as Chinese import data missed expectations, adding to worries about demand weakness in the country. AUD and NZD were also dragged lower, erasing last Friday’s post NFP gains. EUR was also marginally weaker on the day after “sources” emerged this weekend suggesting the ECB is mulling further easing, but was also weighed down by weak trade data from one of the eurozone’s most important trade partners in China. On which note, SocGen suggests that should this week’s US inflation and retail sales data harden the market’s conviction that the Fed will officially adopt an easing bias, the Yen is more likely to gain than the EUR, whose gains are likely to be capped by a weakening CNY. GBP was under pressure from weak April GDP and after Tory leadership frontrunner Boris Johnson kept the prospect of a no deal Brexit alive with some punchy rhetoric. The latest COT data showed that EUR shorts had been pared while specs added to GBP shorts, SocGen notes. JPY was softer on the improved market risk tone and after BoJ Governor Kuroda made dovish comments, in which he opened the door for further stimulus as the central bank seeks to meet its 2% inflation target. CAD was firm, holding on to post NFP gains below 1.3300 vs. the buck, also supported by strong housing data. RUB: ahead of the CBR rate decision this week, RUB was marginally firmer vs. the greenback and hanging around the middle of its 3-month range (63.60 – 65.60). Last week CBR chief Nabiullina hinted again that a rate cut could be considered, as inflation expectations fall. TRY advanced on the day, moving back below 5.8000, despite news Russian experts would visit Turkey on June 28th regarding the controversial S-400 missile system which puts Turkey at risk of US sanctions. Looking ahead, CBRT will set policy on Wednesday.

* CNY: Some have argued that China’s tolerance for a weaker RMB amid trade wars can be seen in the rise of bearish bets, which has seen the CNY/CNH differential to widen to 200 pips (SocGen notes it is three times the average of 66 pips seen in the last year). Indeed, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that it was no coincidence that the yuan had been wallowed to weaken. Analysts continue to digest PBOC Governor Yi Gang’s recent comments; while some desks have suggested that it is a sign that USDCNY 7.00 could be nearing, UBS highlights the following quotes from the PBOC Governor: (1) “I don’t think along the mathematical scale, any number is more important than other numbers” (which the market has read as the dismissal of the importance of 7.00); (2) “The trade war would have a temporary depreciation pressure on Yuan, but you will see after the noise, RMB will continue to be stable and relatively strong compared to EM currencies”; (3) “PBoC is already pretty much not intervening in the FX market for a long time, and I hope that this situation will continue -- not intervene.” UBS says this all sounds like a reminder that the PBOC is capable and will intervene when required. Overnight, the central bank continued to fix the yuan stronger; “It seems that Beijing still prefers a stable yuan and PBOC is likely to frustrate yuan bears in the short-term,” according to the Swiss bank.

subject: Rabobank asks whether the US/China trade war be about to hit Hong Kong
content:
• Over the weekend of the 8-9th June, hundreds of thousands of people marched in protest against extradition bill that would allow for the transfer of fugitives to mainland China. The bill has sparked multiple protests in recent months and condemnation from local businesses. Meanwhile, the US, as they reiterated again this Monday (10th June), has raised concerns that about a continued erosion of the country’s autonomy. Recently, former Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten has called the extradition bill “the worst thing to happen to Hong Kong since 1997” and “would break China’s “One Country, Two Systems” and risk undermining the city’s rationale as an international trade hub” and Germany granted asylum to activists wanted in the country, the first time a foreign country has taken such a move.
  • Rabobank reminds us of the US-China Economic and Security Review Commission’s annual review published in November 2018, which recommended that the US should review its treatment of Hong Kong and China as separate customs areas for dual-use technology exports due to the “troubling” political trends there. “Against the current political backdrop, might the US react to the extradition legislation’s passage by acting on that front?” Rabo asks. In other words, Hong Kong be caught in the crossfires of the US/China trade war?

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Buck wobbles as Trump repeats Chinese tariff warning
content:
DXY

The index remains firm amidst broad Dollar gains vs G10 counterparts, but several EMs led by the Mxn are outperforming on a combination of factors – namely the US-Mexican trade agreement. The DXY is trying to test 97.000 again, and just carved out a marginal new 96.934 high for the day having dipped on comments from US President Trump hailing the success of tariffs as a bargaining chip and stressing that if his Chinese peer Xi fails to meet at the G20 then the additional $300 bn goods could be subject to increased levies immediately.

NZD/AUD 

The Kiwi has been the major laggard all day in wake of latest trade data from China showing a worrying fall in imports, with Nzd/Usd slipping further from initial post-NFP peaks towards 0.6600, while the Aud/Usd held up marginally better around 0.6960 and between 1.0532-00 in cross terms awaiting the return of Australia from a long holiday weekend.

GBP/CHF/JPY/EUR

The Pound lost ground vs the rebounding Greenback on UK specific bearish impulses as April GDP contracted more than expected, while ip, manufacturing and construction output all missed consensus as well. The ONS said a dramatic decline in the production of motor vehicles and general transport equipment were behind the weakness and due to a combination of planned factory closures plus Brexit uncertainty. Cable lost grip of the 1.2700 handle and Eur/Gbp spiked through 0.8900 to circa 0.8930 before oaring some losses as candidates for the vacant Conservative Party leader post delivered campaign speeches and interviews ahead of the official deadline for declaring their challenge. Meanwhile, the Franc and Yen succumbed to a reversal of safe-haven positioning to trade sub-0.9900 and below 108.50 respectively, with the former also softer for choice against a more resilient single currency that held 1.1200 on the Chf cross and 1.1300 vs the Usd where a decent 1.1 bn option expiry rolled off at the NY cut. Eur/Usd also drew some encouragement from no clean breach of chart support at 1.1293 (Fib and 30 DMA), but equally did not revisit Friday’s post-US jobs data highs (1.1348) or test offers said to be waiting around 1.1350.

CAD

The Loonie held on to the bulk of its gains made on last week’s contrastingly upbeat Canadian labour report, with Usd/Cad off lows but capped ahead of 1.3300 between 1.3280-25 and building permits soaring to more than offset a modest housing starts miss.

EM 

The aforementioned US-Mexico deal that averts tariffs, and according to Mexican President AMLO should secure the safe passage of the USMCA through Mexico’s Senate (possibly next week) propelled the Peso through 19.1400 at best, while Usd/Zar and even Usd/Try also reversed relatively sharply from recent pinnacles on the wave of risk-on sentiment and despite ongoing concerns about the state of affairs in SA and Turkey.

The market usually under-prices, not over-prices, the extent of a Fed interest rate cycle, UBS notes
content:
• UBS notes that in last 30 years, the futures market has almost always correctly predicted change of direction of Fed Policy, but tends to underestimate the full-size of the rate cycle; making the current situation, in which 2.5 cuts have been priced for the rest of the year, but the Fed has not yet to committed to a single cut, particularly interesting.
  • On only one occasion since 1988 has there been such a mismatch between Fed policy and the market, UBS points out; in 1992 the Fed cut by 50bps in June, followed by 25bps in August. In September, the market suddenly priced in a further 25bps in cuts but by October this pricing had receded, whilst the Fed stood pat.
  • However, more often “the futures market is caught out by the Fed taking action, as with the surprise rate hikes of 1994,” UBS says, “it's extremely rare the market overestimates the Fed in any case (let alone getting it wrong)”. In other words, the notion that the futures market is over-pricing Fed rate cuts is, based on historical evidence, unlikely. Much more likely is the opposite, the bank argues.

Talking Crude: Prices subdued despite a complying Russia
content:
• The crude complex has begun the week struggling to stay in the green despite bullish comments out of OPEC+, and a rise in risk sentiment after Trump withdrew plans to implement Mexico tariffs. Russian Energy minister Novak told his Saudi counterpart that he is sure Russia will reach their supply cut targets. Novak also said that the scenario of oil prices of falling to USD 30/bbl is not excluded in the event of no supply cut extension. Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin said that Russia doesn’t want to target an oil price but wants a balanced oil market. Analysts at PVM comment, “In other words, the OPEC/non-OPEC alliance is virtually guaranteed to green-light an extension to existing supply curbs.” Multiple analysts had previously expressed the high likelihood of cuts being extended, so it is likely priced in by this point.
  • One could argue that demand fears are overshadowing markets. China’s import data showed it had imported 11.3% less oil in May than its record high in April, falling to 9.44mln BPD. Some of the drop is indeed attributed to the US sanctions on Iranian exports (although analysts note the likelihood of Iran finding methods to continue exporting “off the radar”), but also in the background is the lack of resolve in US-China trade tensions, with fresh tariffs being prepared in the Trump administration’s arsenal ahead of meetings at the G20 summit.

subject: Additional US Equity Stories - US President Trump comments on RTN & UTX, Big Tech, Chinese companies, further on RTN, UTX
content:
US President Trump, when asked about the Raytheon (RTN) & United Technologies (UTX) tie up on CNBC, expressed concern over the reduction in competition within the defense industry, bemoaning the reduction in the number of companies after years of mergers and mentioning that the US military now receives less bids for contracts. He did caveat, saying that he understands sometimes the mergers had been beneficial in preventing the companies from "going bust". Elsewhere, Raytheon  said that if the deal is terminated under specific circumstances, they will be required to pay United Technologies a termination fee of USD 1.785bln whilst under another set circumstances United Tech would have to pay a termination fee of USD 2.365bln.

US President Trump was also critical of the EU's targeting of big US tech firms, mentioning that the US plans to "do things differently" (Companies targeted by the EU include Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and Apple (AAPL)). However, he did doubled down on criticism of some US technology companies for alleged discrimination against the President and other conservative speakers (his criticisms in this regard are usually leveled social media platforms Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR))

US President Trump also mentioned that the US are not planning on targeting Chinese companies and he wants them to do well. He did not mention a bill introduced last week which seeks to increase regulatory oversight of foreign firms listed in the US (which would affect companies such as Alibaba (BABA) and Baidu (BADU).

Microsoft (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) is planning to launch its latest Xbox console, known as Project Scarlett, at the end of next year. Moreover, a new streaming service called Project xCloud will be launched in October, allowing customers to stream games from an Xbox One onto a mobile device. Elsewhere in Xbox related news, Microsoft launched its Xbox Game Pass Ultimate for US 14.99 per month, which includes Xbox Live Gold and over 100 games.

United Technologies (UTX) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) and Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) agreed on Sunday to combine their aerospace businesses to create a new company worth approximately USD 121 billion in an all-stock deal, marking the sector's biggest ever merger. The merger is expected to result in more than USD 1 billion in cost synergies by the end of the fourth year, both companies said. United Technologies (UTX) CEO said that the board of the newly formed firm would comprise of 8 members from UTC and 7 from Raytheon.

Intel (INTC) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) and Qualcomm (QCOM) (Information Technology/Semiconductors), amongst other tech co.s, have told employees not to speak about technology and technical standards with Huawei workers, in response to the recent U.S. blacklisting of the Chinese tech giant. Kraft Heinz (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) announced that the company's internal investigation into its procurement area and assessment of internal controls is complete, and the food maker continues to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation. The co. announced it will take actions to improve internal policies and procedures whilst working to strengthen internal control over financial reporting.

S&P 500

Elsewhere, the aircraft maker will showcase its commercial and defence products, services and technologies at the 2019 Paris Air Show. Elsewhere, American Airlines are said to be considering the purchase of Airbus A321 XLR as a possible replacement for the Boeing 737 MAX.

Salesforce.com (CRM) (Information Technology/Internet Software & Services) has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Tableau Software Inc (DATA) (Information Technology/Software) for an enterprise value of USD 15.7bln in an all-stock deal. The acquisition has been approved by both boards.

OTHER

Apollo Global Management LLC (APO) (Financials/Capital Markets) is reportedly in the lead to acquire Shutterfly (SFLY) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) after making the highest offer for the U.S. digital imaging company. The offer is reported to value Shutterfly at close to USD 2bln, excluding its debt pile of over USD 900mln.

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM, FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) and Renault (RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) are looking for ways to restart their collapsed merger plan and secure the approval of the French carmaker's alliance partner Nissan. Elsewhere, Aurora, self-driving car software startup, said on it would partner with Fiat Chrysler to build autonomous platforms for commercial vehicles.

Insys Therapeutics Inc (INSY) (Health Care/Biotechnology) has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, this coming approximately one week after the drug maker agreed to pay USD 225mln to settle a U.S. probe, in which the co. allegedly paid bribes to doctors who prescribed a specific opioid medication.

Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Rail & Road) subsidiary Motivate will sue the city of San Francisco, alleging it is violating a 10-year exclusivity contract for its for bike-share program.

Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Rail & Road) announced in a regulatory filing on Friday, that Barney Harford, former COO, and Rebecca Messina, former Chief Marketing Officer, will be leaving the ride-hailing co. This comes amid efforts by CEO Khosrowshahi to take more control of operations, who is also overhauling Uber's leadership to deal with brand challenges. Elsewhere, Barron's urge caution on Uber, saying “a bet on Uber stock is a bet that the company can eventually turn a profit but there is no guarantee its version of ride-hailing will pan out down the road.”

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European Indices  [Euro Stoxx 600 +0.2%] are firmer as risk sentiment remains positive after the US agreed to advert tariffs on Mexico
  • In FX, the USD outperforms its G10 counterparts with antipodeans lagging on mixed China trade, while GBP declines with UK GDP
  • Looking ahead highlights include; Canadian Housing Starts & Building Permits, US Jolts, BoE’s Saunders

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week higher with sentiment underpinned after US and Mexico reached an agreement to avert tariffs which were set to kick in today, while the region also took impetus from the last Friday’s gains on Wall St. where disappointing Non-Farm Payrolls data spurred Fed rate cut hopes. Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) was lifted by favourable currency flows and following an upward revision to Q1 GDP, with automakers also underpinned by the tariff-related relief as well as news Fiat and Renault Chairmen discussed reviving their merger plan. Elsewhere, Australia remains closed for holiday, while Hang Seng (+2.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) were positive but with initial weakness seen in the mainland following a net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed Chinese Trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports topped estimates although a contraction in Imports highlighted subdued domestic demand. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially pressured on safe-haven outflows but then staged an aggressive comeback as the declining yield narrative persisted and with the BoJ also in the market for JPY 775bln of JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8925 (Prev. 6.8945)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(May) 279.1B vs. Exp. 136.0B (Prev. 93.57B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (CNY)(May) Y/Y 7.7% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 3.1%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(May) Y/Y -2.5% vs. Exp. 5.8% (Prev. 10.3%)

China is to implement export controls on sensitive sectors to prevent and resolve national security risks, while there were also reports that Chinese authorities reportedly warned several tech companies not to reduce exposure to China more than what was necessary due to trade restrictions or there would be consequences. (Newswires)

G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Chiefs joint communique stated they pledge to use all the policies they can to protect global growth from disruptions due to trade and other tensions, while it added that risks from trade and geopolitical tensions are "intensifying". (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda says the BoJ still has room for big stimulus and reaffirms commitment to use all policy options if risks materialize; and that the BoJ can deliver further monetary stimulus if necessary and will ease further if momentum towards its 2% inflation target is lost. (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

US

US President Trump announced that the US reached an agreement with Mexico and that tariffs are indefinitely suspended, while Mexico agreed to take strong measures to stem the tide of immigration. Furthermore, Mexico has agreed to immediately begin buying large quantities of agricultural products from US farmers. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that he believes Mexico will meet their commitments and that US President Trump retains the ability to impose new tariffs if commitments are not made. (Newswires)

UK/EU

BoE’s Haldane suggested that acting early with a rate hike would ensure against the need for larger hikes in the future and suggested the time is approaching for when a small increase in rates would be prudent. (Newswires)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt said German Chancellor Merkel is willing to renegotiate the Brexit deal with a new UK PM. (Newswires)

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson plans to reduce income tax for 3mln by increasing the 40p rate threshold to GBP 80K from GBP 50K, while he also commented that Britain should be reducing corporation tax and other business taxes. In addition, Boris Johnson has also pledged to withhold the Brexit bill payment until the EU gives the UK better exit terms. (Telegraph)

French President Macron has warned Boris Johnson that Britain's economy will be downgraded and plunged into turmoil if the UK withholds the GBP 39bln Brexit divorce payment from Brussels. (Telegraph)

EU is to warn businesses not to expect any help regarding a no-deal Brexit and urges them to prepare for the UK to crash out of the EU on October 31st. (FT)

UK GDP Estimate MM (Apr) -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.10% (Prev. -0.10%)

- UK GDP Estimate YY (Apr) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.70% (Prev. 1.90%)

- UK GDP Est 3M/3M (Apr) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.40% (Prev. 0.50%)

- UK Manufacturing Output MM (Apr) -3.9% vs. Exp. -1.0% (Prev. 0.9%)

- UK Construction O/P Vol MM (Apr) -0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. -1.9%)

- UK Industrial Output MM (Apr) -2.7% vs. Exp. -0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

- UK Goods Trade Balance Non-EU (Apr) -4.595B GB vs. Exp. -4.476B GB (Prev. -4.361B GB, Rev. -6.217B GB)

- ONS note that the GDP fall is mainly due to ‘dramatic fall’ in car production due to planned shutdowns and amidst Brexit uncertainty. UK motor production -24% MM, the biggest monthly decrease since record began in January 1995; the broader transport equipment category showed the biggest fall since 1974.

ECB policymakers are said to be open to lowering rates if growth weakens according to sources which noted that the case for more QE is less clear, while there were separate comments from ECB's Weidmann that the German economy could decline slightly. (Newswires)

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio states that he expects PM Conte and Deputy Salvini to agree on a minimum salary, tax cuts and fight to privileges at a meeting on Monday. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Hong Kong’s Leader Lam has stated she will not abandon plans to allow extradition to China, in-spite of the mass protests; stating that the law is necessary and safeguards to human rights are in place. (BBC/Guardian)

Iran has not seen practical tangible measures from the EU thus far to salvage the Nuclear Deal, according to Iranian Foreign Minister spokesman. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are marginally higher [Stoxx 600 +0.2%] following on from a positive Asia-Pac handover, with sentiment underpinned by the US-Mexico trade agreement, albeit with the positive momentum fading as Washington’s trade spat with China remains a grey cloud over the market. UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.5%) marginally outperforms its peers as exporters in the index benefit from a weaker domestic currency, whilst German, Swiss, Austrian and Norwegian cash markets are closed due to Whit Monday. Sectors largely reflect a “risk-on” mood as defensive sectors such as Utilities, Healthcare and Consumer Staples lag their peers. In terms of individual movers, BAE Systems (+1.2%) shares are supported in light of a mammoth merger between US listed Raytheon (RTN) and United Technologies (UTX), which some say point to renewed demand in the sector; the merger of equals will result in the new Co. having a annual revenue of around USD 74bln. Elsewhere, Fiat Chrysler (+2.2%) shares spiked higher amid reports of potential renewed talks with Renault (+2.1%), with the former also potentially buoyed by the US-Mexico trade agreement as it is one of 8 automakers with plants in the South American country. Finally, Thomas Cook (+14.5%) shares were bolstered by acquisition chatter as Forsun (18% shareholder) is reportedly planning a potential offer for Co’s tour arm which generates sales of GBP 7.4bln.

FX

USD - The Greenback has extended its recovery from Friday’s lows, albeit in part due to renewed weakness in rival currencies and despite outperformance in certain EMs on fundamental and technical factors. The DXY just topped out a fraction below 97.000 having declined to sub-96.500 in wake of a weak BLS report that raised already lofty market expectations for Fed easing, with the focus now switching to upcoming CPI data to add more justification for the FOMC to deliver a cut.

GBP - Not the biggest G10 loser, but Sterling has been one of the weakest majors in early EU trade on the back of monthly GDP for April showing a faster than forecast contraction in the UK economy as ip, manufacturing and construction output all slumped more than anticipated. The ONS assigned much of the blame to planned shutdowns and Brexit uncertainty that led to a record decline in car production, while transport equipment tanked the most since 1974. Cable duly retreated through 1.2700 in response and Eur/Gbp breached 0.8900 to post 5 month+ peaks.

NZD/AUD - The main victims of a slump in Chinese imports, but somewhat perversely it is the Kiwi that is feeling the brunt of the data that exacerbates US-China trade tensions rather than the Aussie and perhaps due to Australia’s national holiday. Nzd/Usd is hovering just above 0.6600 vs Aud/Usd holding around last Friday’s low and several key technical support levels either side of 0.6950, like 10 and 21 DMA convergence circa 0.6955 and a Fib at 0.6945, while the Aud/Nzd cross is hugging the upper end of a 1.0525-00 range.

JPY/CHF/EUR - The US-Mexican trade accord has seen the Yen and Franc lose safe-haven appeal and retreat vs the Buck to 108.50+ and 0.9900+ respectively, but Usd/Jpy faces some upside hurdles in the form of 1.1 bn option expiries at the 109.00 strike and then trend-line resistance at 109.15, while Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf (latter pivoting 1.1200) will be conscious that Thursday’s SNB quarterly policy review is looming. Elsewhere, Eur/Usd is testing 1.1300 and bids below the big figure after a brief and minor breach of Fib/30 DMA support at 1.1293 amidst more bleak Italian data that was only partly attributed to calendar distortions due to a national holiday, per ISTAT. Note also, decent expiry interest at 1.1300 in 1.1 bn.

CAD - The Loonie remains relatively bid after Canada’s healthy jobs release in contrast to the US and with some extra encouragement via contagion from the aforementioned US-Mexican agreement that bodes well for USMCA prospects. Usd/Cad off lows but still well under 1.3300 in a 1.3278-25 band and near multi-month lows ahead of Canadian housing starts and building permits.

EM - As noted above, several regional currencies outpacing the Dollar and none more so than the Peso in relief that Mexico will avoid US tariffs – Usd/Mxn sub-19.2000 and down through 19.1400 at one stage. Meanwhile, the Rand and Lira are also doing well, albeit in corrective moves after hefty losses of late on a steep deceleration in SA GDP/SARB mandate uncertainty, and ongoing US-Turkey strains, as attention turns to the upcoming CBRT policy meeting. Usd/Zar has reversed from 15.0000+ to around 14.8500 and Usd/Try down towards 5.8000, but conversely Usd/Cnh remains close to recent 6.9600+ peaks on the drop in Chinese imports.

FX Expiries of note:

- EUR/USD: 1.1300 (1.1BLN), 1.1310 (200M)

- AUD/USD: 0.6950-60 (362M), 0.7000 (820M), 0.7025-30 (330M), 0.7060 (883M)

- USD/JPY: 107.00 (3.4BLN), 108.00-20 (1.3BLN), 108.75-85 (600M), 109.00 (1.1BLN)

FIXED INCOME

Gilts have rebounded from deeper 130.13 Liffe lows in wake of the broad UK data misses (trade aside) that hardly support any change in the current BoE stance as opposed to inferences from Haldane that a pre-emptive hike might be prudent. However, the 10 year benchmark remains ¼ point+ below parity having just held above last Friday’s 131.09 session base and as Bunds extend their losses to over ½ point at 171.13 amidst a broad downturn in Eurozone bonds including BTPs in wake of weak industrial output. Similarly, US Treasuries remain close to overnight session lows and the curve has steepened further in wake of the US-Mexican breakthrough.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are mixed as the energy complex continues to consolidate following its recent sell-off, with the benchmarks somewhat underpinned by the risk appetite around the market after US President Trump called off tariffs on Mexico which were due to be imposed today. WTI and Brent futures currently hover just above USD 54.00/bbl (ahead of its 200 DMA at 52.60) and USD 63.00/bbl respectively. Turning to OPEC, Saudi’s Energy Minister echoed some comments from the back-end of last week in which he stated that Russian is the only country still undecided on an OPEC+ deal extension, and subsequently, Russia’s Finance Minister noted that Brent prices could potentially fall to USD 40/bbl if the deal is not extended. Elsewhere, amid the possible ramifications of the US-Sino trade war on the global economy, Barclays revised its 2019 oil demand forecast lower by 300K BPD to 1.3mln BPD (in-line with IEA’s 2019 forecast of 1.3mln BPD and marginally higher compared to OPEC’s forecast of around 1.21mln). In terms of precious metals, a firmer risk tone and a stronger Greenback have shaved off some gains in gold (-1.0%) and silver (-1.5%), whilst copper (+0.7%) prices benefit from the risk appetite after Washington struck a deal with Mexico. Finally, iron ore futures are marginally firmer as a firmer Buck caps gains in the base metal, despite China’s iron ore imports rebounding from an 18-month-low last month, against the backdrop of tight supply amidst the recent production disruptions including Vale’s shipment cuts and China’s smog alerts.

Russian Energy Minister Novak says the scenario of oil prices falling to USD 30/bbl is not excluded in the event of no extension to the global oil deal. Separately, Russian Deputy Energy Minister Sorokin states that we do not target an oil price, we target oil market balance, Russian intends to return to 100% compliance with the global cut deal in June, and that in general the OPEC+ charter has been agreed which is to focus on co-operating in general, without any specific numbers. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister said the country does not have plans to leave OPEC. (Newswires)

Barclays has downgraded 2019 global oil demand forecast to 1.3mln BPD (Prev. 1.6mln BPD), citing weaker activity in most major economies. (Newswires)

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures gap down pre-UK data and more BoE speakers
content: The 10 year debt future and 3 month strip are conforming to bearish leads and factoring in rather hawkish rhetoric from BoE’s Haldane ahead of another speech from the MPC member and scheduled comments from Saunders later. The core bond resumed Liffe at 130.31 and remains on the back foot alongside core counterparts within a 130.23-38 range vs last Friday’s 130.62 close, while STIR contracts are flat to 3 ticks adrift in advance of a domestic data deluge at 9.30 am, including April GDP, ip, manufacturing and construction output plus trade. Looking at the charts, Friday’s 130.67 highs represents near term resistance and short term technical suggest support ahead of 130.00.

subject: TIMETABLE FOR THE NEXT UK CONSERVATIVE LEADERSHIP ELECTION
content:
*JUNE 7th – Theresa May resigns

*JUNE 10th - Nominations open at 1000BST and close at 1700BST on Monday 10 June

  • MPs must submit their names with a proposer, seconder and six more MP backers to the Tories' backbench 1922 Committee
  • Every Tory MP gets one vote and any who are away on the ballot days get a proxy vote

*JUNE 11th - The 1922 Committee hosts a husting at 1500-1900BST and continue at 1600BST-1800BST the next day with all candidates

*JUNE 13th - Tory MPs hold their first ballot to carve out the least popular candidate between 1000BST and 1200BST

  • MPs vote for their chosen candidate and the person with the fewest votes is eliminated.
  • Also eliminated are any candidates who get less than 16 Tory MPs backing them - 5% of the Parliamentary party
  • The vote takes place in Parliament and the losers are announced at about 1300BST
  • The results are announced in alphabetical order

*JUNE 17th - Tory MPs hold their second hustings from 1500BST to 1900BST

*JUNE 18th - Second ballot of Tory MPs, from 1500BST to 1700BST and the result is announced at around 1800BST

  • Anyone fewer than 32 Tory MPs backing them (10% of the party) is automatically eliminated

*JUNE 19th/20th – Further ballots

  • Ballot 3 is 1500BST to 1700BST on Wednesday
  • Ballot 4 is 1000BST to 1200BST on Thursday
  • Ballot 5 is 1530BST to 1730BST on Thursday
  • Once there are only two candidates on the ballot, the full vote by Tory members can begin

*JUNE 22nd – Votes by members begin - Tories' 160,000 members spend a month deciding who will lead their party 

*JULY 22nd - Next Prime Minister confirmed

subject: European equity movers this morning: Thomas Cook (TCG LN) +20.0%; Mediaset (MS IM) +5.5%; Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) +2.3%; Renault (RNO FP) +1.2%; Ferguson (FERG LN) -4.2%; Hargreaves Lansdown (HL/ LN) -2.7%
Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih says Russia is the only country still undecided on an OPEC+ deal extension
Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
Airbus (AIR FP) – American Airlines (AAL) has stated that it is to remove Boeing 737 Max flights from its schedule until September 3rd, which was previously due to end on August 19th. Will impact around 115 flights per day. (FT)

Mediaset (MS IM) – Co. are to create a new holding company which is to be based in the Netherlands and become the parent group for the Spanish & Italian businesses; while the Co. attempts to create a European TV group. New company, MediaForEurope, is to be dual-listed in Italy and Spain, with Italian fiscal residence. (FT)

Ferguson (FERG LN) – Co. reports Q3 revenue +6.2% Y/Y to USD 5.274bln. Ongoing trading profit at USD 359mln. Co. announces a USD 500mln share buyback programme. Performance is in-line with guidance. Net debt USD 1.588bln vs. Prev. USD 1.582bln (Newswires)

Air Liquide (AI FP) – Co. are to divest its dedicated gasses complex to Fujian Shenyuan, transaction is to have a limited unfavourable one-off impact on H1 2019 net profits. Co. maintains FY guidance. (Newswires)

Fincantieri (FCT IM) – Head of Italian state mender expects Co’s proposed acquisition of Chantier de l’Atlantique to get the green light from Brussels. (Newswires) 

Metso (METSO FH) – Co. have signed an agreement for the acquisition of McCloskey International, which will accelerate their growth in aggregates. Expected to close during Q4 2019, with a bilateral loan from Nordea Bank for the acquisition. Agreement has an enterprise value of EUR 279mln. (Newswires)

St. James’ Place (STJ LN) – Co. discloses a 3.2% stake in Taylor Wimpey (TW/ LN) and a 5% stake in Crest Nicholson (CRST LN). (Newswires)   

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Co. has invested in newly emerging vertical farming industry via a JV and an acquisition. (Newswires)

Ericsson (ERICB SS) – Co. and Intellectual Ventures have signed a license agreement which ends all paten infringement lawsuits between the companies. Ericsson expects a negative impact on operating income within the Segment network in Q2 2019. (Newswires)   

Eurofins (ERF FP) – Co. notes that forensic investigations are ongoing in regard to a cyber-attack announced on June 3rd. Co. will provide an update on FY impact at the end of August. (Newswires) 

Thomas Cook (TCG LN) - Co. confirms that it is in discussions with Forsun in regard to a prelim approach. Co. says there can be no certainty that the approach will result in a formal offer. (Newswires)

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM)/Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) - US President Trump stated that the US and Mexico have reached an agreement to avert tariffs. (Newswires)

BP (BP/ LN) – Co. are seeking buyers for its stake in Shearwater oilfield in the North Sea, following talks with Shell (RDSA LN) fell through, according to sources. (Newswires)

SMITH & NEPHEW (SN/ LN) INITIATED WITH SELL AT SHORE CAPITAL 

GENERALI (G IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM SELL AT CITI

subject: Bunds: backing off further from post-NFP contract highs
content: Dovish ECB sources aside, risk-on sentiment spurred by the US and Mexico clinching a deal to avert tariffs indefinitely has prompted a deeper retreat in core bonds from Friday’s intraday peaks forged in wake of meek US jobs data. Meanwhile, relative resilience or stability in Italian BTPs may also be sapping some safe-haven strength from the 10 year German benchmark that is hovering just above a 171.42 Eurex low vs 171.66 at best and the 171.72 previous settlement. In terms of technical pointers, June 7’s 171.80 contract best forms the next line of resistance, while 171.25 represents hourly support on some charts ahead of a Fib level just above 171.00.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

** GERMAN, SWISS, AUSTRIAN AND NORWEGIAN STOCK MARKETS WILL BE CLOSED TODAY DUE TO WHIT MONDAY **

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week higher with sentiment underpinned after US and Mexico reached an agreement to avert tariffs which were set to kick in today, while the region also took impetus from the last Friday’s gains on Wall St. where disappointing Non-Farm Payrolls data spurred Fed rate cut hopes. Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) was lifted by favourable currency flows and following an upward revision to Q1 GDP, with automakers also underpinned by the tariff-related relief as well as news Fiat and Renault Chairmen discussed reviving their merger plan. Elsewhere, Australia remained closed for holiday, while Hang Seng (+2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were positive but with initial weakness seen in the mainland following a net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed Chinese Trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports topped estimates although a contraction in Imports highlighted subdued domestic demand.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices are firmer with sentiment bolstered by the US and Mexico reaching an agreement to avoid tariffs
  • Sources indicate that ECB policymakers are said to be open to lowering rates if growth weakens
  • In FX, the USD has benefited as tariffs were avoided with MXN outperforming; GBP is subdued as the Tory leadership contest begins
  • Looking ahead highlights include; UK GDP, Services, Industrial & Manufacturing Output, Canadian Housing Starts & Building Permits, US Jolts, ECB’s Stournaras, BoE’s Haldane & Saunders

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week higher with sentiment underpinned after US and Mexico reached an agreement to avert tariffs which were set to kick in today, while the region also took impetus from the last Friday’s gains on Wall St. where disappointing Non-Farm Payrolls data spurred Fed rate cut hopes. Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) was lifted by favourable currency flows and following an upward revision to Q1 GDP, with automakers also underpinned by the tariff-related relief as well as news Fiat and Renault Chairmen discussed reviving their merger plan. Elsewhere, Australia remains closed for holiday, while Hang Seng (+2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were positive but with initial weakness seen in the mainland following a net liquidity drain by the PBoC and mixed Chinese Trade data in which Trade Balance and Exports topped estimates although a contraction in Imports highlighted subdued domestic demand. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially pressured on safe-haven outflows but then staged an aggressive comeback as the declining yield narrative persisted and with the BoJ also in the market for JPY 775bln of JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 50bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8925 (Prev. 6.8945)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(May) 279.1B vs. Exp. 136.0B (Prev. 93.57B). (Newswires) Chinese Exports (CNY)(May) Y/Y 7.7% vs. Exp. 4.7% (Prev. 3.1%) Chinese Imports (CNY)(May) Y/Y -2.5% vs. Exp. 5.8% (Prev. 10.3%)

China is to implement export controls on sensitive sectors to prevent and resolve national security risks, while there were also reports that Chinese authorities reportedly warned several tech companies not to reduce exposure to China more than what was necessary due to trade restrictions or there would be consequences. (Newswires)

G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Chiefs joint communique stated they pledge to use all the policies they can to protect global growth from disruptions due to trade and other tensions, while it added that risks from trade and geopolitical tensions are "intensifying". (Newswires)

Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires) Japanese GDP (Q1 F) Y/Y 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.1%)

GEOPOLITICAL

Hong Kong’s Leader Lam has stated she will not abandon plans to allow extradition to China, in-spite of the mass protests; stating that the law is necessary and safeguards to human rights are in place. (BBC/Guardian)

UK/EU

BoE’s Haldane suggested that acting early with a rate hike would ensure against the need for larger hikes in the future and suggested the time is approaching for when a small increase in rates would be prudent. (Newswires)

UK Foreign Secretary Hunt said German Chancellor Merkel is willing to renegotiate the Brexit deal with a new UK PM. In other news, UK Work and Pensions Minister Rudd said she is backing Foreign Minister Hunt for Tory leadership. (Newswires/Telegraph)

Conservative leadership candidate Michael Gove was fighting last night to save his campaign to become prime minister as he faced calls of hypocrisy over his use of cocaine before he entered politics. (Times)

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson plans to reduce income tax for 3mln by increasing the 40p rate threshold to GBP 80K from GBP 50K, while he also commented that Britain should be reducing corporation tax and other business taxes. In addition, Boris Johnson has also pledged to withhold the Brexit bill payment until the EU gives the UK better exit terms. (Telegraph)

French President Macron has warned Boris Johnson that Britain's economy will be downgraded and plunged into turmoil if the UK withholds the GBP 39bln Brexit divorce payment from Brussels. (Telegraph)

EU is to warn businesses not to expect any help regarding a no-deal Brexit and urges them to prepare for the UK to crash out of the EU on October 31st. (FT)

ECB policymakers are said to be open to lowering rates if growth weakens according to sources which noted that the case for more QE is less clear, while there were separate comments from ECB's Weidmann that the German economy could decline slightly. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the breakthrough by US and Mexico to avert tariffs helped the DXY recoup some of Friday’s losses in which a miss in headline NFP jobs data and weaker than expected earnings growth saw the probabilities of July cut by the Fed increase to just under 90% from around 70% the prior day. The greenback’s NAFTA counterparts were also underpinned from the agreement with MXN the outperformer after having strengthened by nearly 2%. EUR/USD pulled back with ECB policymakers said to be open to lowering rates if growth weakens and GBP/USD was mired by political uncertainty as the Tory leadership race begins to heat up with front-runner Boris Johnson promising to raise the Higher income tax rate threshold, as well as withhold paying the divorce bill until the EU offers better Brexit terms. Elsewhere, USD/JPY benefitted from the risk appetite and USD-recovery, while antipodeans were softer with AUD/USD back below the 0.7000 handle amid the absence of Australia, disappointing Chinese Imports data and as CNY traded at its weakest since November last year.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures underpinned by the risk appetite after US and Mexico reached an agreement to avert tariffs, with a decline in the Baker Hughes rig count and recent announcement of fresh sanctions on Iran’s petrochemical sector adding to the bullish pressure on oil. Elsewhere, gold declined nearly 1% overnight with the precious metal weighed on by safe-haven outflows and a recovery in USD, while copper benefitted from the positive risk tone but with gains capped after the mixed Chinese trade data.

Baker Hughes Rig Count: oil rigs -11 to 789, gas rigs +2 to 186 and total rigs -9 at 975. (Newswires)

Iran Oil Minister said the country does not have plans to leave OPEC. (Newswires)

US

A disappointing NFP report saw the curve bull-steepen in an immediate response, as traders raised bets that the Fed will cut rates either in response to weakness in some gauges of economic activity, or in an “insurance” manner to extend the recovery. The probability of a June rate cut was up to around 22.5%, July rose to just under 90% (from around 70% on Thursday). Trump’s jawboning efforts resulted in some selling action in the afternoon, however, at settlement, major curve spreads were modestly narrower (2s30s was around 1bps lower, having been at 9bps wides after the payrolls data). US T-note futures (U9) settled 9 ticks higher at 127-07.

US President Trump announced that the US reached an agreement with Mexico and that tariffs are indefinitely suspended, while Mexico agreed to take strong measures to stem the tide of immigration. Furthermore, Mexico has agreed to immediately begin buying large quantities of agricultural products from US farmers. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated that he believes Mexico will meet their commitments and that US President Trump retains the ability to impose new tariffs if commitments are not made. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: US has provided some Chinese products additional time to avoid a tariff increase in which tariffs on some goods were postponed to June 15th from June 1st; Participants await Chinese Trade Data
content:
Country Garden Holdings (2007 HK) - Co. May contracted sales fell 4.9% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Tech - Taiwan bans China-made semiconductors from cable TV boxes. (SCMP)

Trade

US President Trump said on Friday that China is subsidising its products in order for them to continue to be sold in the USA and reiterated that many firms are leaving China for other countries including the US in order to avoid paying the tariffs. Furthermore, Trump added that there was no visible increase in costs or inflation and that the US is taking in billions. (Newswires/Twitter)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin commented that Huawei discussions are about national security and are separate from trade, while he added that President Trump could ease restrictions on the Co. if trade talks progress. Mnuchin also commented that he had constructive talks with PBoC Governor Yi Gang which included candid talks on trade, while he also suggested that China has allowed to let the CNY depreciate. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative’s office on Friday stated that US has provided some Chinese products additional time to avoid a tariff increase in which tariffs on some goods were postponed to June 15th from June 1st. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said we should find a trade solution despite the disagreements we have. In related news, there were comments from China Global Times Editor that China wants a deal although it must be a fair deal, otherwise China will continue with the trade war no matter how long it lasts. (Newswires/Twitter)

Chinese authorities reportedly called on several tech companies to warn them not to reduce exposure to China more than what was necessary due to trade restrictions or there would be consequences. (Newswires)

Other News - PBoC Governor Yi Gang reiterates that China has plenty of room regarding interest rates and RRR, as well as for fiscal and monetary tools. (Newswires) 

Protests - More than 1mln were reported to have conducted a protest in Hong Kong regarding new extradition law with mainland China in which some injuries were reported due to some violence. (Newswires)
